page.prototype: Result_Flag as L = email_send2(P pMessage [,C profile [,L lSilent [,L store_in_mailbox [,L autowrap ]]]])

argument.name: pMessage
argument.description: A pointer variable containing the message.

property.name: To
property.description: A semi-colon (;), comma (,), or CR-LF delimited list of recipients. Microsoft Outlook allows you to format the address as "recipient_name<recipient@address>". This hides the "<recipient@address>" portion of the field from the recipient.

property.name: CC
property.description: The CC list. Multiple entries are separated by commas.

property.name: BCC
property.description: The BCC list. Multiple entries are separated by commas.

property.name: Subject
property.description: The subject line of the email. Optional, depending on mail server requirements.

property.name: Message
property.description: The body of a text message. Optional, depending on mail server requirements.

property.name: Html_Message
property.description: The body of a HTML message.

property.name: Attachments
property.description: A semi-colon (;), comma, or CR-LF delimited list of filenames. Any file type can be attached.

property.name: Xmailer
property.description: Default = NULL. The sending email program.

property.name: Lrelated
property.description: Default = .F. .T. = Attachments are embedded image in the HTML message. .F. = Attachments are separate files.

property.name: Date
property.description: Default = "". The date of the email.

property.name: Failure
property.description: Default = "". A list of failed addresses.

description.p: Default = "". Optional email headers. Email headers are specified as a CR-LF delimited list of colon separated name-value pairs. Headers can be one of the standard mail headers or a user-defined header. Prefix user-defined headers with "X-".

p.example: dim headers as c =<<%str% Reply-To: info@example.com X-company: Example Co X-campaign: Spring Launch %str%

description.p: See *[extlink:RFC 822@https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc822#section-4.7]* to learn more about message headers.

property.name: Success
property.description: Default = "". A list of successful addresses.

property.name: ReturnReceipt
property.description: Default = .F. If .t. then an e-mail will be sent to the sender acknowledging that the recipient has read the e-mail. Note that not all e-mail clients support this feature and the recipient might decline to send the receipt.

argument.name: profile
argument.description: Uses the last active profile. The name of an email profile as found on the View > Settings > Email > Profiles tab.

argument.name: lSilent
argument.description: Default = .F. Allows you to trap errors using the Xbasic ON ERROR GOTO command. .T. = Error trapping on. .F. = Error trapping off.

argument.name: store_in_mailbox
argument.description: *[Desktop Applications Only]*. Whether to store the message in your mailbox. .T. = Alpha Anywhere stores a copy of the message in a DBF table. .F. = Copy not saved.

argument.name: autowrap
argument.description: Default = .T. Whether to force text emails to wrap at 72 characters per line. .T. = Automatically wrap all lines of text at 72 characters or less. .F. = Leave text email body unchanged.

return.name: Result_Flag
return.description: Indicates success or failure after sending an email. If *[xb:Result_Flag]* is *[xb:.F.]*, the email was not sent. If *[xb:.T.]*, the email was sent.

section.important: In web applications [EMAIL_SEND_NOPROFILE()] is preferred because this function does not rely on an e-mail profile.

EMAIL_SEND2() requires that you have configured an Alpha Anywhere email profile. If you are working in an environment where this is not possible, use [EMAIL_SMTP_OPEN()], [EMAIL_SMTP_SEND()], and [EMAIL_SMTP_CLOSE()].

section.description: EMAIL_SEND2() sends an email message using Alpha Anywhere's built-in email features. The function does not require that you have a third party email client (such as Eudora or Outlook ) installed on the computer.

section.note: EMAIL_SEND() is not sensitive to the type of image files attached and embedded in HTML formatted messages.

section.title: Example
section.description: Sends an email message using Alpha Anywhere's internal email facility. A copy of the message is stored in the user's Alpha Anywhere outbox, a DBF table.

important.p: The *[xb:store_in_mailbox]* argument is not supported in web applications.

section.example: dim message as P body = <<%a% Just wanted to let you know that we really enjoy using Alpha Anywhere. %a% message.message = body message.to = "sales@alphasoftware.com" message.subject = "Thanks" email_send2(message, "", .F., .T.)

section.description: The Silent option is useful for Xbasic programmers who are using the EMAIL_SEND2() function in a loop where they want to prevent the standard Alpha Anywhere error messages from popping up when an error (such as a bad email address) in encountered. Instead, they want to write their own error handler for this condition. For example:
section.example:
Dim tbl as P Dim ITbl as P Tbl = table.open("customers")
Query.filter = "balance > 1000000" Query.order = "recno() "
ITbl = tbl.query_create() Tbl.fetch_first()
While .not. tbl.fetch_eof()
ON ERROR GOTO BAD_EMAIL

section.description: Fill in all of the arguments for EMAIL_SEND2() and set the Silent parameter to *[xb:.T.]* .
section.example:
Email_send2(message, profile, .t.) ON ERROR GOTO 0 'turn error handler off Tbl.fetch_next() End While Tbl.close() ' end the main script here so that it does not continue into the error handler End
BAD_EMAIL: ' put you own error handling code here
RESUME NEXT ' causes Alpha Anywhere to resume on the line after email_sends() end

section.title: Embedding Images in an Email
section.description: This example shows how to include an image in an email. Note that *[xb:pm.lrelated]* is set to *[xb:.T.]*. This allows the image attached to the email to be referenced in the email body.
section.example:
dim pm as p pm.attachments = "C:\login.jpg" pm.lrelated = .T. pm.from = "aaron@alphasoftware.com" pm.from_alias = "Aaron Brown" pm.to = "aaron@alphasoftware.com" pm.subject = "Inline Attachments" pm.html_message = <<%html% This is a message with an
inline image. %html% email_send2(pm)
